summary.topic: welcome to writing 101 and fed 14, hope you're having a good day
summary.summary: welcome to writing 101 and fed 14. hope you're having a good day. let's dive into a framework for writing that i've been thinking about: writing is not just...

summary.topic: writing isn't just words on a page; it's holistic
summary.summary: writing isn't just words on a page. it's more holistic, and i want you to start thinking about what writing really means.

summary.topic: it's a powerful way to shape the world through words in emails, tweets, and videos
summary.summary: personally, i think it's the most powerful way to shape the world. for the longest time, we've been just putting words into emails, tweets, and videos. it's about inviting and connecting with people.

summary.topic: inviting people into your mind and stories is key to effective writing
summary.summary: people connect with your stories and view of the world. when you hear "i'm glad my mom died," it might evoke thoughts like abuse or resilience. it's a powerful phrase that captures attention and invites deeper emotional engagement immediately.

summary.topic: don't separate visuals from writing; it's part of a greater whole
summary.summary: don't separate visuals from writing; they form a greater whole. pairing them can influence the tone, whether psychopathic or sad.

summary.topic: the title of a book paired with visuals can change its tone
summary.summary: the book "i'm glad my mom died" is known for its contrasting title and cover—sad and negative yet bright and comedic. it's written by an actress who humorously talks about her mother's life, although the deeper story is actually sad. many of you have asked how to write engaging copy, and we should start by focusing on the overall process.

summary.topic: knowing what good writing is starts the process
summary.summary: good writing is clear, concise, and engaging. just like good design, it effectively communicates its message and keeps the reader's attention without unnecessary fluff.

summary.topic: good writing needs to be clear, meaningful, and persuasive
summary.summary: good design means clear, meaningful, and persuasive writing. we'll break down what each of these mean and how to achieve them. first up, clarity.

summary.topic: if people don't understand what you're saying, they won't care
summary.summary: understand what you're trying to say, they won't even care, and the worst case scenario is that you put something out into the world. people

summary.topic: the worst scenario is people scrolling past your content
summary.summary: people often scroll past tweets without understanding them, especially poorly written ones as seen in crypto or web3 content. it's crucial to communicate clearly and provide value, whether that's saving time, money, or offering entertainment. here's an example of a successful cold email.

summary.topic: communicate something of value, whether saving time, money, or making people laugh
summary.summary: made an irreversible decision so this email is about shan perry looking to hire people. hey sean, i made an irreversible decision just 30 days ago.

summary.topic: a clear and meaningful email example was shared to highlight importance
summary.summary: i quit my job because the opportunity cost of not being full-time in crypto was too high. so, i'm on the market and you should hire me to run nft experiments for milk road. marketing is about getting someone to take action, like buying your thing.

summary.topic: persuasive writing aims to make someone take action
summary.summary: sign up for a subscription or adopt your point of view means convincing someone that what you're offering is valuable or that your perspective is correct. think of Bill's 2424...

summary.topic: buildspace focuses on storytelling and marketing to convey their education model
summary.summary: we discussed our view on education and how to improve it during the live stream. sean effectively engages the audience by presenting two clear ideas, which simplifies their decision-making. the key takeaway is to work backwards from your intent when crafting your message.

summary.topic: start writing by working backwards from intent; know what you want to say
summary.summary: it's tough to clearly communicate the main message. i've noticed this issue frequently, even our content team struggles with it. my approach: keep shooting and figure it out.

summary.topic: keep shooting and figure out your target through continuous posting
summary.summary: you need to keep posting to get feedback and find out if you're targeting the right audience. think of this as a process. writing regularly is crucial; many of you already do, and if you don't, you should start.

summary.topic: writing for yourself helps to articulate ideas and intent
summary.summary: our team spent a lot of time writing to understand what we're building. for example, we went off the grid for a month to figure it out. the forcing function that works well for us is when we're...

summary.topic: communicate new ideas clearly to your audience through writing
summary.summary: crafting a new message involves a lot of trial and error. we focus on what we want to convey, our mission, and the different segments of our audience. we iterate through various drafts, aiming to clearly tell people what we're doing next, why it's meaningful, and persuade them to engage with us.

summary.topic: intent helps make everything else easier but is difficult to figure out
summary.summary: when they figure out s5 is delayed, they'll be really disappointed, so we need to lift their spirits by explaining the reason clearly. working backwards from intent is crucial but tough. how confident are you that your writing is clear and understandable? I'll give you a shout out later, D.

summary.topic: clear communication is key to effective writing
write with an eraser; often cut out extraneous things to improve clarity
summary.summary: make sure your writing communicates your initial intent clearly. we always say write with an eraser; cut out extraneous stuff that doesn't matter. that's the difference between clarity and clutter.

summary.topic: avoid extraneous details and focus on what truly matters
summary.summary: like story time we'll get to that but actually a lot of times, have you...

summary.topic: the principal of inversion helps to identify what not to do to achieve goals
summary.summary: charlie munger, warren buffett's right-hand man, often talks about the principle of inversion—figuring out what not to do to achieve your goals. for example, if you want to write more, stop doing things that distract you. in a hiring scenario, filtering out unsuitable applications is more effective than trying to fit everyone in.

summary.topic: example exercise: revise a video producer job application for clarity
summary.summary: has some experience and with a little more time, it could be much stronger. let's do this exercise and i'll come in to help you guys.

summary.topic: identifying what's extraneous in writing can significantly improve it
summary.summary: start erasing unnecessary bits to improve clarity. delete the second paragraph if it's redundant, and focus on establishing legitimacy briefly by mentioning your experience and portfolio. ensure the tone feels like you're applying rather than doing them a favor. if it's a video application, include relevant video links instead of a cold, text-heavy intro. make sure everything feels personal and relevant to the recipient.

summary.topic: showing examples of bad and good writing emphasizes the importance of style
summary.summary: there's no easy way for someone to make a decision. i rewrote this to give you my take. now you're going to be...

summary.topic: use clear, simple language to keep the audience engaged
summary.summary: jeff's writing style may seem unconventional, but it shows a deep understanding of the creative process and the importance of context. he praises bill's fresh take on education and expresses a strong desire to collaborate, highlighting his past experience in startups and media. jeff emphasizes his willingness to learn and adapt, offering to improve bill's youtube presence and suggesting a chat to discuss potential collaboration.

summary.topic: better communication often involves breaking down complex ideas simply
summary.summary: my teammate alec inspired me to share something cool about sticker mule. their marketing hits hard with simple, effective emails. for example, an email selling custom tape at a discount grabs attention with minimal effort. clear and concise content generates interest and builds trust quickly.

summary.topic: writing for people who are meaningful to you makes content more engaging
summary.summary: knowing your audience means writing for people who are meaningful to you. just like the movie "everything everywhere all at once" was clearly crafted for a specific crowd, your writing should also be targeted. this approach ensures authenticity and connection.

summary.topic: storytelling in writing connects deeply with the audience
summary.summary: write meaningful content, even if it's simple. consider who you're writing for and make it genuine. many posts, especially on platforms like tiktok and instagram, can feel formulaic. connect with your audience by writing something that matters to you. stay authentic, it pays off in the long run. for example, taylor swift's song "all too well" wasn't expected to be a hit but became a fan favorite because it was genuine. authenticity is key.

summary.topic: understanding your own preferences can guide better content creation
summary.summary: image she actually turned it into a short film starring the girl with red hair from stranger things, and it's pretty good. i bring up artists for inspiration because they tell great stories you can apply to your brand, even in SaaS. to be persuasive, write clearly and meaningfully, showing up consistently with authenticity and value, like how navid improves his emails daily by providing helpful information.

summary.topic: clear and meaningful writing builds trust and engagement
summary.summary: hey, pat here. happy wednesday. i have a confession: starting a story would have failed miserably without the r/entrepreneur subreddit. i hacked it to get millions of free users for $0, even crazier, i did it when i was a nobody. keep sentences short to build that rhythmic flow.

summary.topic: short sentences and avoiding jargon help in building writing momentum
summary.summary: keep sentences short, whether writing or making videos. in videos, use short dialogue and let visuals convey more. take tyler the creator's lyrics: "i'm sorry i'm sorry i don't see you more," and see how each short line builds momentum. focus first on clarity for 95% of persuasive writing. the rest will follow.

summary.topic: example of persuasive writing: use rhythm and repetition for impact
summary.summary: the speaker explains the effective use of storytelling and tone in advertisements and emails, using examples from a whiskey ad for Father's Day and an email from a company called Build Space. they highlight the power of repetition and emotional connection in the whiskey ad, and discuss the importance of readability and audience awareness, referencing the Hemingway app. they emphasize keeping writing simple, authentic, and practice-driven to strengthen brand voice over time.

summary.topic: buildspace emphasizes casual, engaging writing style
summary.summary: we kept our latest nights and weekends post straightforward to reach a broader audience for our DMW lectures. it's neutral without losing our voice, but simple and clear. we're focusing on building an audience, even if it means posting content that's not quite perfect and tweaking it based on feedback, much like taylor swift's approach to her song "all too well."

summary.topic: balancing engagement metrics with authenticity helps improve content
summary.summary: getting feedback right means directly asking "hey, i saw you signed up for my app, why am i sending this email?" a small addition could be showing you want to make it better for the person. a good title for this would be...
